lines.text: Busy, Busy, busy, always busy.
[last lines]
Can you see them?
The whales have all gone.
You can't never tell. You can't never tell.
Photographs fade. Memories live forever.
that's all we need.
Well, I've been thinking for a long time, you should ask Anna to take Libby.

[shaking her head]
She wouldn't.
Oh, why not? She has plenty of money. She'll see that her mother is well cared for.
[long pause by Sarah]

[sighing]
Well Sarah, you know what Harry Truman said.
What.
Well, if the buck is going to be passed, it may as well be passed to somebody with plenty of them.
He never said that.

[laughing]
Of course he didn't.
It must take great courage to go on alone.
No, not courage, my dear, nothing so heroic as that. Merely a considerable investment of will.

[recounting his mother, in the time of Imperial Russia]
She said, "Nikolai, our Empress is gone. There will no longer be any use for any of us. You must leave me now and go into the world." Then she handed me a handkerchief - in which she had wrapped all of her remaining jewelry. She made me take it.
My mother kissed me and said, "Use my treasure for your needs, my son, but in the end, be able to say that it was well spent."
to expect nothing.
I have once again been set adrift.
Oh, I'm sorry, Mr. Maranov.
Oh, you needn't be, my dear. I have often been adrift - but I have always stayed afloat.
But all these years, what have you done?

[pauses to reflect]
I have spent my life... visiting friends.
What are you doing?
I'm dusting.
Busy, busy, busy. Always busy. I wish we were in my house in Philadelphia.
Oh, but it's so hot in Philadelphia now.
I like the heat. It keeps you from being so busy.
Well, dear, this is Maine... and this is my house... and somebody has to keep it tidy.
